Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 09:38AM Melanie_Ann wrote: I too, Love EVOO but do not like olives...my mom thinks it's weird, but they do definitley have a different taste. However, I noticed after chemo that I can't taste olives so my mom puts them on pizza when she makes it. I know my taste is back when I can taste an olive. Black Bean Pineapple Enchiladas Ingredients: 1 red bell pepper 1/2 medium white or yellow onion: chopped 1 tabelspoon olive oil 1 15 oz can of black beans; drained 1 20 oz can of crushed pineapple in pineapple juice 1 rotisserie chicken Cilantro (optional) 1 cup Mexican shredded cheese 1 large can of enchilada sauce 10 to 12 medium-size multigrain flour tortillas Directions: Dice the red bell pepper and onion and saute in olive oil over medium heat or until tender. Add drained black beans and pineapple including juice into the skillet. Stir and heat. Pull apart white meat chicken and shred. Add chicken to the skillet and cook till hot.  Two, 9x13 glass or casserole dishes. Lay one tortilla in the dish and scoop approximately 1/2 cup filling into tortilla filling center end to end. Tuck 2 edges of the tortilla over and roll the untucked side completely enclosing the filling. Place seam-side down in dish. Stuff and roll the rest of the tortillas the same way until dish is full. Pour the enchilada sauce over the top and sprinkle cheese on top. Bake at 350 degrees for 15 minutes until bubbly hot. -I got this recipe out of a book. This is the original recipe. I didn't have a rotisserie chicken because I don't live where I could get one. So I baked some chicken breasts and used those. It was a little labor intensive recipe but only because I made it that way. I'm sure the rotisserie chicken would save time. I also didn't used the canned enchilada sauce. I made my own. I'm not really sure I liked the kind I made so next time I think I might find a natural canned sauce or omit it alltogether. I think they would have been just as good without the sauce. Als, this made a lot! I think I actually got about 17 enchiladas out of it. Definitely way too much for 3 people. So we're having leftovers! It was a really good/different type of Mexican. The filling is a little sweet due to the Pineapple so it's not a typical mexican flavor.  - I got a short walk in yesterday. My arm has reallllly been hurting. I have that axillary web syndrome and it's so painful. It flairs up at the oddest of times. I missed my PT appointment this week due to having tests run for chest pain. SO, hopefully next week she'll be able to help me. I did do as many exercises/stretches for my arm as I could and it does feel better today. I can't wait until I have it healed so I can start some resistance training with my arms again.  Wow my post is already huge so I'm going to stop there! I hope everyone has a healthy and productive day. This thread keeps me motivated!

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2011 07:41AM Melanie_Ann wrote: First off- I exercised yesterday! I went to national dance day practice. We are doing a flash mob dance at our local farmers market tomorrow morning. Maybe you'll get to see it on FB. One of the girls said she would post it. She's making her husband come and tape us...lol. ***Now for my Rant*** So I go to Rads today for my 1st of 5 boosts. Only 4 more days of radiation for me! So I was excited. But where do I start with the frustration? I feel like my doc talks to me like I'm 5 and he doesn't explain things very well. I asked him SEVERAL times where the boosts were going to be. He said, to the original tumor bed. So I said..no more to my lymph nodes right? He said correct. Well lo and behold, they radiation my axilla today. I mean...I consider those my lymph nodes. So I ask him. I thought we were just radiating the tumor bed on the breast...he said yes, that's right. I said..so why did they radiate my axilla today? He said to get the tumor from the other side...I said. oh that makes sense. So they're not radiating my axilla. He said...yes they are. OMG. I just don't understand him. GRRRRRRRRRR and that's not even where it ends.  So my skin is getting super red! And it kind of hurts to stretch my skin at all (like putting my arm over my head.) So the techs told me to ask for silvadene cream. I said..oh can you only get that once your done with treatment? They said..no, you can use it the whole time. So i'm thinking to myself..why do they wait until there is a problem to treat it? But I wasn't too concered at this point. So when I saw the doc today I asked about silvadene. Well..I find out I'm allergic. It has sulfa in it. So nix that idea. He said, don't worry, the nurses will come up with something else. So she comes back in and tells me about this radiation gel strips that they have. But they are out. So they send me to wal-mart to get some and told me to bring them back and they would help me apply them. So I go. I get there and ask. They don't know what I'm talking about. She gets the pharmacist. He says he has ordered some for the cancer center yesterday but they are on back order until MID AUGUST! I said..well I won't need them then. I just wanted to start crying. Can they be any more frustrating. I mean..don't you think you should watch your supply and make sure you have enough? Especially for pt's with allergies! So I'm going back to the cancer center here in a minute to talk to them. I'm frustrated beyond belief if you can't tell. =) Thanks for listening! Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 11:49AM Melanie_Ann wrote: I have this recipe for tortilla chips. 1 c. yellow cornmeal 1/2 c. warm water 1/2 tablespoon fresh lime juice 1/2 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon pepper Combine all ingredients in a bowl. Stir mixture until dough forms a ball and holds together. (Itw ill be a wet dough.) Add a little water if necessary, a tabelspoon or two at a time. Cover bowl with plastic wrap, and let dough rest at room temperature for 30 minutes. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Using yoru hands, press dough out onto an ungreased 17-inch baking sheet, making it as thin as possible. Use a knife to cut chips into 2-inche squares. Bake 20 minutes, or until slightly browned and crispy. -I got these from a book - The ultimate guide to the Daniel Fast by Kristen Feola. We do the Daniel Fast for 3 weeks every year at my church. And its basically a diet that contains no yeast, sugar, meat, artificial sweeteners, refined and processed foods, deep-fried foods, and solid fats. I've found it very helpful even now, to have healthy recipes.  I made those tortiall chips once. Be careful if you try them, b/c about half of mine burnt to the pan. But the rest were pretty good.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 09:40PM Melanie_Ann wrote: I met my goals today Yay! Although, I almost got completely side tracked and forgot what I said I would do. I was making dinner this evening, homemade chicken nuggets and mac and cheese. I also made kale chips which turned out aweful, so my mom made some broccoli to make up for it. I haven't had mac and cheese in probably years but found a good recipe in a magazine and decided to try it. It was different than your good ole kraft but I thought it was even better. So as I'm making up a plate, a car pulls up in our driveway and my dad asks, who's car is that? I have no idea, but figure it's one of my dad's clients. (He's a lawyer and his office is in our house and he often has ppl show up at odd times to talk) So I go about my business but look back outside to see one of my best friends from high school getting out of the car. I respond with, Oh it's Kylea. Then my eyes get huge and I'm like...OMG it's KYLEA. haha...she moved to Alaska 8 months ago and I didn't think she was coming home for a visit until the fall. Well she got some unexpected time off and flew in today and suprised her parents and then came to see ME! She only told a few people she was coming in case she didn't get to see many people, but she told my mom 4 weeks ago to make sure I would be home. I was so ecstatic! I just couldn't believe it and it was soooo good catching up with a friend who flew 4000 miles to see me. =)  So anyways, after she left, I couldn't remember what I had planned for the evening, but finally did. So I made it back to the good old treadmill, walked about 45 min and then did some squats and lunges. Whew my legs were burning! But it feels good! Then I did some arm stretches and my lymph massage. -I should have known there were probably already recipe threads..duh. I just haven't looked. I like sharing here too! Rennasus- a hike sounds like so much fun. I should find someone to go hiking with me. I can't remember the last time I did that.  Does anyone else have a supersonic sense of smell after chemo. I was sitting in the living room today and kept getting a wiff of something awful. Turns out it was bad oranges in our kitches in the other room. ugh...bad smells really nauseate me! And when oranges go bad, they really stink. I'd rather do that walk through the citrus farm! Especially packing material in anything we get in the mail...so weird.  Anyways, wanted to share my good story of the day and the fact that I met my goals. I should know that I always feel bad for a week and not be so hard on myself. But when I start to feel good, I'm always in a much better mood.  Have a good day tomorrow laides. I'll be thinking of you tomorrow Maria when you do chemo. Tomorrow right?

Well I got out my little appt card to see exactly what time it was and it was in 20 minutes!  I had to call and reschedule b/c I live 45 minutes away...and I'm still in my  pajamas...haha. OOps! I have too many appointments! I'm going on a little retreat this weekend so you won't hear from me. I get back Sunday night. So I hope everyone has a wonderful weekend! Painfree and worry free! Supersally- sorry you had a stressful day. Happy Birthday! I hope the evening went a little smoother. Maria- I don't know about you, but I get more anxious and irritated when they tell me to take more medicine. That's exactly what I don't want to do. I'm sorry you're feeling anxious. I hope all your plans work out for your good. Maybe you won't have to be at work too long... I keep wondering if I'm pushing myself too much by still trying to work full time...i.e. missing appointments. I'm so scatter-brained, and feel like I'm putting thousands of miles on my car. I'm almost looking forward to radiation b/c I'm moving up near the hospital where I get treatment for 6 weeks. I feel as though I'll be less stressed b/c that will take away some of my job responsibilities (although I work mainly from home)  and other responsibilities at home. All of my friends were teeny tiny. It took me awhile to realize that all of their constant comments about my big boobs was because they were jealous. So then, when I faced a mastectomy, I was horrified. I learned to appreciate myself in a whole new way. I chose not to do the mastectomy and just do a lumpectomy. So my D cups are still hanging around and I couldn't be more thankful!  Redsky- Happy Anniversary!  Rennasus- A getaway sounds soooo nice! My family was going to go on vacation in June but  now I think we're going to post-pone. =( I just can't fit it in with all these appointments. So hopefully we'll get to go in August. Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 08:26AM Melanie_Ann wrote: Renn-miaderm is not a prescription. You can order it offline at www.miaderm.com. There is a local pharmacy where I am that carries it b/c the radiation department requested it. I know there are prescription creams that you can get but my insurance wouldn't cover any so they recommended miaderm. They said it worked as well as the others and was cheaper if you didn't have insurance. 7 down and so far, so good. I was excited today b/c I found out that I only have radiation 4 times next week due to the holiday. The tech girls acted bummed that I was so happy I wouldn't have to see them one day. They were kidding. They said it would probably be nice for me to have 3 days off. And they're right! Maria- the occupational therapist that I'm seeing for my LE says she hasnt really seen LE that has presented like mine. It's mainly in my hand and the worst in my palm. She said she usually to never sees it in anyones palm. So she's called at least one other LE therapist that she knows to ask and she also said she doesn't usually see it. So she wanted me to ask my oncologist. So I did...and he said he didn't know. Of course... So I guess it's working a little bit if I constantly wrap and massage my arm every single day. If I miss a day, it puffs back up. They also said that it probably does that b/c I'm actively undergoing treatment and that once I'm done, it should settle down. I'm getting used to it a little. But that does NOT mean I want it to stay. Thanks for asking! Renn- definately request some PT!!!! I had cording as well and it took seeing 3 PT's for them to take me seriously. I INSISTED! Mainly b/c I was having rads and I've read that it will only make it worse if you don't take care of it before hand. My arm is soooooo much better. It's still slightly stiff when I raise it all the way up but before I couldn't even lift my arm up halfway straight. And my cording is pretty much gone! But if you do go, do not over do it! I think that's what started my lymphedema. They overstretched my arm and caused it to flair up. I'm almost convinced of it.  Shannon- You're doing great with exercise but I agree with Maria- adding at least one day at the gym would be so good for you! Or do you have hand weights? You could follow along on a dvd at home if you're too self conscious to go to the gym right now. I don't have a gym membership so that's what I normally do.  Sue thanks for the advice on the pic forum. I actually wasn't sure how to get on it. Is it the same one you were talking about in your previous post? that I have to message someone? Thanks! Are your bras underwire? I need some without underwire but I'm a D and it's a little hard to find a good bra without underwire. I've read that underwire can make your LE flair up, expecially in your back.  Ugh and all this talk about Tamoxifen...I'm not looking forward to it. I start after radiation. And I'm still constantly getting hot flashes and my weight has been creeping up, not down. But I feel like finally (hopefully) I'm getting into some sort of routine. So I need to pick back up with the exercise. It's been a few days. I had a friend come visit me this weekend. It's hard to get in exercise with visitors b/c I always feel like I need to entertain. So, back at it for me today. It's nice weather so I should be able to go for a nice walk/run. So my oncologist wanted to see me today. He emailed me late last night and told me to have them page him when I arrived this morning (for labs and radiation). His nurse then saw me and said he had something he wanted to ask me. I was sooo curious. But then my friend showed up and went with me to see him and he didn't end up asking me anything. He said he just wanted to see me, to see how I was doing. He is leaving for India this week for 3 weeks. And I see him when he gets back. It was a little strange. In addition, he had called me over the weekend b/c he wanted to ask me a question. He wanted to know how I handled my diagnoses and treatment so well. He said he had never met anyone as calm and peaceful as me. hehe...it was a little strange but nice. I shared with him my faith and God and also talked about my support system on here and in my community. So today, I thought he was going to ask me more about it, but there were others in the room so I'm not sure if he really wanted to talk about that, or really just see me before he left. So who knows...maybe I'll find out.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2011 09:01PM Melanie_Ann wrote: So yesterday I felt more awful than I thought. I was having horrible chest pain at times. I finally broke down and called the ONC and he had me come in today for testing to rule out pericarditis or a PE, etc. Good news is, everything was normal and my heart is still as healthy as ever! He thinks it could be esophagitis or costochondritis. So then he tells me to take Tylenol. Wish I would have done that first...haha. I have felt much better this evening after doing that. And I suffered for 2 days! I was a little worried though. So, in other words, I haven't really exercised in the past 2 days. Spent all day today at the Cancer Center...bleh. I think I get nauseated now just being there. Although the people are super nice so that's a plus. Anyways, my goal this week is to first start some walking again and get the blood pumpin. Then I'm going to start some strength training in my core and legs since I have been severely lacking in that department the past couple of months. My arm is still a little messed up from surgery with some webbing so I need to get stretching (which I did yesterday!) Yay me. So the resistance training will have to wait on the arms. Just wanted to let you know my goals for this week. =) It helps to speak them out, so I will have to actually keep to my word and do them! Maria- I think the blog idea would be wonderful! I would be a faithful follower. Suebee-I used to get terrible shin splints in high school. It wasn't until college, when my coach finally evaluated my running stride and bought me shoes for my stride/weight/body type, that I haven't had much of a problem with shin splints since. And I used to go to PT 3 times a week for a couple of years for them. Now, that may not be the case with you, but just wanted to share what worked for me if you really miss it. I sometimes think I need to do other excerising b/c my body is so used to running. Maybe next I'll try some Pilates or Yoga. I've heard it's good for BC patients. Supersally-I heard ya about the rough weekend. I had one too! Chemo is not for the faint of heart. Did someone say that on here and I just totally copied them? I can't remember. =) sorry if I did, but it must have stuck with me. Annie-washing hair sounds nice. I can't wait until I have hair again to wash. I love the feel of the water running through my hair...ahhh. -Seriously, I don't know how I would do any of this without my mom. She takes me to all my appointments and takes care of me afterwards. Even listens to me whine and complain. Today she got up bright and early to drive me an hour and a half to get all my testing done. Then, halfway through the day she started not feeling well. So it turns out, when we get home, she has a fever! And I've been around her all day with no immune system. I need some prayers tonight! Ok, I just wrote a book. I'm excited to start my day tomorrow with some exercise. I will report back.

Posts.Content: May 22, 2011 10:24AM Melanie_Ann wrote: Maria- I'm all up for a visit in Amersterdam or Kansas City...lol. At least I know you would be a healthy host! =) And I love to travel. We should all try to meet up one day when we're "done." -On the food note- I am also hormone positive and at first was deathly afraid to eat anything. I lost about 15 pounds but I was just so darned worried all the time. So I will share an experience I had with you. We had a guest evangelist come and speak at our church back in February. He was done preaching and then all of a sudden said, wait a minute. I have a word for someone here. He then opened his Bible- and I honestly can't remember the scripture, but it was all about do no worry about what you eat, etc, etc. I'll try to find it. So then he said, the Lord does not want you to fret and worry over what you eat or don't eat. Whether this type of meat or sugar is going to harm you. I felt like he was specifically speaking to me. He said, pray over you're food and the Lord will bless you. I don't want to live in worry or fear the rest of my life about what I eat because I think it detracts from the joy of it. Now, don't get me wrong. I still want to eat as healthy as possible, because honestly it just makes me feel good. But I don't want the fear. So I've taken to praying over my food much more than I used to. I still struggle with it. Even last night, on the phone with my best friend, I was saying..'I just don't know what to do! I don't know how cautious to be or not to be.' Bless the Lord, my friend takes me seriously and she is praying about it with me and for me. When I come to any realizations I'll let you know. It is a hard place to be. We want to be so in control of something we may or may not of ever had any control over.  I love your recipes though and your strive for better health and food, because I honestly am starting to enjoy it too. I love to cook/ bake and it just feels better, knowing it's better food. But I just still am struggling with fear. So I just eat as well as I can at home and try not to stress when I go out. I still make healthy choices but I know I can't control whether the meat is hormone free or not at most restaurants. And I think it's perfectly reasonable to take your own food to your MIL's house. If you don't like the food, bring your own! I don't think I could eat what she had. It kind of makes me sick to even think about it. And I'm just going to keep praying. For guidance specifically. Because that's all I know to do. =) Just my two sense in a book form..haha. I hope it helps some. Keep sharing with us. My friend also said that the Lord doesn't give us knowledge and expect us not to do anything about it. I do think commerically processed food is not good and could stand to be improved. I started planted a garden a couple years ago. I feel I'm at least doing something... The weather is gorgeous here today as well! I'm looking forward to at least a walk outside and hopefully planting some flowers for my mom today. I do it every year for mother's day but I'm a little behind. I'm so glad to be done with chemo. I feel like I can start expecting to have good days and to keep feeling better and better.  I'm so glad for our group here and support! Makes me smile to come and 'chat' with you all. I hope everyone has a great day. And that those TE's and incisions don't cause too much stress today.

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2011 06:59AM Melanie_Ann wrote: I had my follow up appointment yesterday with my ONC. I just love him! We went over all of my continuing SE's from chemo. He assured me that they were all normal...(headaches, back pain, neuropathy, fatigue..etc.) He said though that if I want a follow up PET scan then we can do it, but suggested it not be for a few months after radiation as it would cause the whole thing to light up with suspicious spots. I so don't want that so I'm content to wait. I go back in 2 months to see him. Then I met with the RAD ONC. He was a nice man but not like my ONC. =( It made me a little sad being passed onto the next Dr. I had to explain EVERYTHING again...the last 6 months. It was a little sobering b/c most of the time I don't think about it. My appointment went well though and the staff is nice. I go in next Tuesday for my simulation and should start the next week. I have to have 33 treatments. I'm moving closer to the hospital for that time so I don't have to drive so far. I was excited b/c they have lots of gyms and pools in the area which we don't have where I live. Then the RAD ONC said..no pools! booo! He said the chlorine would burn my sensitive skin. Anyways...it was a long day. I didn't get home until 8 pm. But then my mom and I walked 2 miles. Maria I'm starting to feel the chemo legs! They are soooo sluggish. And I think I'm more fatigued now than ever before. I took 3 naps yesterday during all of our time in the car. I just couldn't stay awake.  And I think it is perfectly normal to be emotional. I go to bed every night and prepare to roll up all my bandages, do my LE massage and then re-wrap. Sometimes I cry all the way through it. It's just not how I envisioned the rest of my life... Well I'm off to try to work some today. It's really hard to stay focused these days but doing my best. I hope everyone has a wonderful National BFF day!

I was young though so I can't remember too much. Renn- yay for a successful surgery! I hope you're feeling good today and that drain isn't causing you too much pain. Let us know about the infection results. Julie- Rads isn't so bad. Except I feel exteremely tired sometimes. I'm trying to let myself relax and take naps when needed but sometime I just feel like I need to get things done. =/ I met with my RO on Tuesday and he just about made me cry. Not b/c he was nice...but b/c his remarks about my LE not being so bad really upset me. I held it in until I left. I hate for people to see me cry. Sometimes it just comes out of nowhere! Oh, and one of my tattoos seems to have disappeared. It's so strange. They put one on my nipple and we can't find it anymore...lol. Oh well..they have 4 others to go off from.  Sue-enjoy the rest of your trip! Marie- glad you're feeling a little better.  Yay for clean margins and clear path results! Shannon- enjoy your trip! A cabin in the woods sounds soooo relaxing! Let us know how it goes. Well I'm officially 1/3 of the way done with rads. I've had 13/33 treatments done! I'm just a little pink. As I was saying earlier, my RO made me cry on Tuesday. He was examining my hands and looking at my LE hand and he was trying to mumble his way through telling me it didn't look that bad. He said it's really very mild and that cosmetically didn't really look much different than the other hand and if he were not a medical professional then he would have no idea. I looked him straight in the eye and said, "my top concern is not how it looks, it's how it feels, and how I can no longer do many things like I used to." He said..like what? So I said...brushing my teeth, putting makeup on, writing and typing are difficult...and then I drew a blank although I know there are many more. He said..obviously it is affecting you more on the inside than on the outside... haha..I don't know. I think he was trying to sympathize with me in some weird way but it just really upset me. At one point he was like, is there anything that we can do more that we're not doing? I said...I have no idea. I just wanted out of there. It's just so upsetting that they have no clue about treatments for such a common condition probably concerning many of their patients.  Other than that horrible conversation, I've had a pretty good week. I've just been trying to work and sleep. =) Oh, and eat. It seems like that's all I have time for and the next thing I know it's time for bed. Whew, radiation is a little exhausting having to go everyday. I'm going to a family reunion this weekend. I'm excited to see all of my family until I remember how different I look. I just want to be normal for a day without all of the questions on how I'm doing, what's rads like...etc, etc. But I will definately have a good time at my grandmas. She's the best! Ok, that's all for now. I have a friend coming later. I think we should go do a little shopping and eating to make me feel better. Have a great day all!

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 08:18AM Melanie_Ann wrote: I am also going through TAC right now. I'm part of the February group but wanted to comment about TAC. From what I can tell, everyone's experience is different. Even with the same regimen. I've had 2 cycles so far and I have a horrible few days. I start feeling side effects almost immediately in the chair. I get indigestion and then nausea. I've also had swelling of my hands and feet. And then extreme fatigue. I get my treatments on Tuesday and pretty much sleep from Tuesday evening until Friday midday. Then I start to feel better. It's really hard for me to stay hydrated during that time, b/c even the thought of water makes me nauseated.  Then I get stomach cramps and diarrhea. But I'm not complaining here. I think it's better than consitpation. =)  Hopefully my Onc and I can work something out for next time to where I'm not so nauseated and also don't have the indigestion. I seem to have a very sensitive GI tract though.  I hope yours went much better than mine did the first time around. =) I start to feel good after about 4 days so then I have 2.5 weeks where I feel pretty good until the next time. So I know it could be worse and try not to get too upset about all the SE's. Melanie
